Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Assessment of NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure from 2005 to 2020 in China.

AbstractText: Nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) is a major air pollutant with serious environmental and human health impacts. A random forest model was developed to estimate ground-level NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations in China at a monthly time scale based on ground-level observed NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations, tropospheric NO<sub>2</sub> column concentration data from the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI), and meteorological covariates (the MAE, RMSE, and R<sup>2</sup> of the model were 4.16 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, 5.79 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, and 0.79, respectively, and the MAE, RMSE, and R<sup>2</sup> of the cross-validation were 4.3 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, 5.82 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, and 0.77, respectively). On this basis, this article analyzed the spatial and temporal variation in NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure in China from 2005 to 2020, which effectively filled the gap in the long-term NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure assessment in China. NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure over China has significant spatial aggregation, with high values mainly distributed in large urban clusters in the north, east, south, and provincial capitals in the west. The NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure in China shows a continuous increasing trend before 2012 and a continuous decreasing trend after 2012. The change in NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure in western and southern cities is more influenced by population density compared to northern cities. NO<sub>2</sub> pollution in China has substantially improved from 2013 to 2020, but Urumqi, Lanzhou, and Chengdu still maintain high NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure. In these cities, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) could reduce NO<sub>2</sub> population exposure through more monitoring instruments and limiting factory emissions.
